questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Quickly swerve your vehicle into the other lane.
questions.explanation: Always check your mirrors and use the proper signal when changing lanes. Be sure there is enough space for your entire vehicle in the next lane before you begin moving.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the most slippery surface?
questions.answerB: Ice that is wet
questions.explanation: Ice becomes wet when the weather is just warm enough to melt the ice slightly. Wet ice is much more slippery than ice that is not wet.

questions.question: How can you prevent drowsiness before a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about four hours of sleep.
questions.answerB: Plan stopping points into your trip in advance.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on a long trip, strategies include getting adequate sleep beforehand; planning out the route and stopping points in advance; driving with a passenger; and driving at times during which you are normally awake.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Replace a tire.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: Bracing is used to:
questions.answerA: Make items stand taller in a trailer.
questions.answerB: Prevent items from moving in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to unload items from a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit. Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and on the sides of a piece of cargo to prevent movement. Bracing prevents movement by reaching from the upper portion of a piece of cargo to the floor and sides of the cargo compartment.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Increases your braking distance.
questions.answerC: Creates a loud squeaking noise when being used.
questions.answerD: Helps to ensure control while braking.
questions.explanation: ABS increases a driver's control during braking. It will not necessarily change the distance needed for a vehicle to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When slowing down, you should ____ to warn other drivers
questions.answerB: Sound your horn
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it can be a good idea to lightly tap your brakes. This will cause your brake lights to flash, providing a warning to motorists behind you.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but do not need to be repaired immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system is responsible for supporting a vehicle, supporting its load, and keeping its axles in place. When inspecting your vehicle, check for damaged or missing spring hangers, spring leaves, shock absorbers, u-bolts, and frame members. Broken parts in the suspension system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: A vehicle that is smaller than your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Will usually be able to stop faster than your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Will usually take more time to stop than your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will take about the same amount of time to stop as your vehicle.
questions.explanation: In general, a smaller vehicle will be able to come to a complete stop faster than a larger vehicle. Keep this in mind when determining your following distance.

questions.question: When approaching an active railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear any approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train as it approaches.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of the train's horn.
questions.answerD: There will always be flashing warning lights.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing, do not assume that you will hear an approaching train. Trains may be prohibited from sounding their horns in certain areas, or the sound of its horn may be covered by noise from your vehicle. Do not assume that warning lights or other signals will announce a train.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: More than two inches
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: When checking your tires as part of the pre-trip inspection, you should look at the:
questions.answerB: Tire color.
questions.explanation: When checking your tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, it is important to verify that the tire pressure is neither too low nor too high.

questions.question: While operating a CMV:
questions.answerA: You are not required to wear a safety belt.
questions.answerB: You are only required to wear a safety belt if your vehicle does not have airbags.
questions.answerC: You are required to wear a safety belt, but only if hauling more than 1,000 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerD: You are always required to wear a safety belt.
questions.explanation: A safety belt is your best defense in the event of a collision. You must always wear a safety belt while operating a CMV.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerB: You are making a turn.
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before entering a curve. Decreasing your speed before entering the curve will allow you to maintain better control over the vehicle throughout the curve.

questions.question: Skids caused by over-acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.explanation: A skid caused by over-acceleration can be resolved simply by removing your foot from the accelerator. Skids of this nature happen most frequently on surfaces covered in snow or ice.

questions.question: A lane change:
questions.answerB: Should be done slowly.
questions.answerC: Should be done with a jerking motion.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should be made slowly and smoothly.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerA: Should be used together on all axles.
questions.answerB: Should be used together, but only on the rear axle.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, ensure that radial and bias-ply tires are not being used together.

questions.question: When completing a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerB: Avoid regular exercise.
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: When driving in the winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: The air conditioning unit
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is especially important to make sure the coolant and antifreeze are at safe levels.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: Turn on their emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important that you turn on your emergency flashers as a warning to other drivers. This is especially important if you are stopped at night.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: While passengers are on board a bus, refueling the bus in an enclosed space, allowing the bus to be towed, and conversing with the passengers are considered to be:
questions.answerB: Acceptable practices.
questions.explanation: Bus drivers should not engage in conversation with passengers, fuel a bus inside an enclosed building, or tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle. These are all considered to be prohibited practices.

questions.question: When driving with passengers, a bus driver should:
questions.answerA: Engage in conversation with the passengers.
questions.answerB: Not engage in conversation with passengers.
questions.answerC: Ask passengers to watch out the windows for hazards.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming distracted, a bus driver should not engage in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.answerB: Exercise
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Increase the space in front of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.answerB: Glued down.
questions.explanation: Cargo on flatbed trailers or trailers without sides must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling in transit.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Always pump the brakes several times before holding down the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Brake normally.
questions.answerC: Press down the brake pedal as hard as possible every time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers of vehicles equipped with ABS and drivers of vehicles without ABS should brake in relatively the same manner. When ABS is working properly, it automatically applies when brakes are applied in situations that may create lockup.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes:
questions.answerA: Other vehicles will likely get out of your way.
questions.answerB: You should change lanes slowly and smoothly.
questions.answerC: You should wait to change lanes until you are in an intersection.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should always be executed slowly and smoothly. This will result in safer handling of your vehicle while allowing time for other drivers to react to your movements.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: What do headers do?
questions.answerA: Protect the driver during a crash
questions.answerB: Provide a place for storage
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards protect the driver from the forward motion of their cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: If pulled off to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow your taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerB: Turn on your emergency flashers to warn other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other motorists.
questions.answerD: Keep your door open to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop and park on the side of the road, make sure to turn on your emergency flashers. This is especially important at night. Taillights are not an adequate when alerting other drivers because the drivers may mistakenly think your vehicle is moving normally and collide with it.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult for the driver to see behind the trailer.
questions.answerB: There may be extra weight in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Trailers are not made to be driven in reverse.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Ignore their gestures.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driving hazard?
questions.answerB: An open road
questions.answerC: A police car assisting a motorist on the side of the road
questions.explanation: Passing an accident scene can be hazardous because the people involved in the accident may not be watching traffic, and the scene itself may distract other passing drivers. Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions because they attract children who may not pay attention to nearby vehicles. Shoppers near the roadway are often paying attention to stores, not passing traffic.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact and do not gesture at them. Report them to the appropriate authorities once you can safely do so.

questions.question: A bus should be refueled:
questions.answerA: In a closed building while passengers are on board.
questions.answerB: In any location while passengers are on board.
questions.answerC: Without passengers on board, unless absolutely necessary.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board, unless it is absolutely unavoidable. A bus with passengers on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: Which of the following does not indicate bad brakes?
questions.answerB: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should move your vehicle quickly.
questions.answerB: You should move your vehicle slowly.
questions.answerC: The move should be made with a jerking motion.
questions.answerD: You do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly to maintain control of your vehicle. Doing this will also allow a driver that you did not see time to move out of the way of your vehicle. Use the proper turn signal to communicate with other road users.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should be done to prevent the shifting of cargo.
questions.answerC: Can only be done with metal pieces.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are techniques to keep cargo from shifting in transit. A piece of cargo should be blocked to its front, back, and/or sides to prevent movement.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.answerB: Does not cause problems.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: After starting a trip while transporting cargo:
questions.answerA: You will not need to inspect the cargo.
questions.answerB: The cargo should only be inspected if it is making noise.
questions.answerC: The cargo should only be inspected if there is an obvious concern.
questions.answerD: The cargo should be inspected after 50 miles on the road to ensure it is still properly secured.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When should you watch out for black ice?
questions.answerB: When the temperature is below freezing and the road looks wet
questions.answerC: When the temperature is above freezing and there is snow on the ground
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. Be alert to black ice any time the temperature is below freezing and the road surface looks wet.

questions.question: The overhead inside mirror should be adjusted to see:
questions.answerA: Outside of the driver’s side of the bus.
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.answerC: Students in the first four rows of the bus.
questions.explanation: The top portion of the overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: Over-length loads require:
questions.answerB: Roads to be closed to other traffic.
questions.answerC: A person to walk alongside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads may require special permits from the Department of Transportation.

questions.question: How far in advance of a school bus stop should a bus's lights be activated?
questions.answerB: 5 to 10 seconds
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating flashing amber warning lights, they should be activated at least 200 feet (approximately 5 to 10 seconds) before a stop, unless state law requires otherwise.

questions.question: After a bus trip is completed, the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be returned without an inspection.
questions.answerB: Should be inspected.
questions.explanation: Buses should be inspected at the end of every trip. Key safety items could have been damaged by passengers, so an inspection allows these damages to be repaired before another trip is made.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: You should cover cargo:
questions.answerA: To protect the cargo from thieves.
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather.
questions.answerC: To prevent other drivers from looking at what is being transported.
questions.answerD: To keep the cargo a secret.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: Alcohol begins to affect the body:
questions.answerB: After several drinks have been consumed.
questions.explanation: Alcohol consumption impairs muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, vision, judgement, and inhibition. For some people, signs of impairment may begin with the first drink of alcohol. It is safest to not operate any motor vehicle after consuming alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Two
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle transporting hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: Someone other than the driver should do it.
questions.explanation: Always turn the engine off before refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials. Someone must always be at the nozzle controlling the fuel flow.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: If a shipping paper has both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.answerC: Written the same way as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When a shipping paper includes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, one acceptable method of identifying the hazardous items is to highlight them in a contrasting color.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.answerB: Attend hazardous materials training courses.
questions.explanation: While the manual includes all of the information required to pass the hazardous materials knowledge test, you should consider reading the manual as only the first step to learning about the topic. You can learn more by reading and understanding the federal and state rules about the transportation of hazardous materials, as well as by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: How often do hazardous materials employees need to be trained?
questions.answerB: At least once every three years
questions.explanation: Employees who work with hazardous materials must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerB: Value of the materials.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper, which placard must be displayed?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.answerB: After unhooking the hoses.
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: ____ are used to warn others of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Flashing lights
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on bulk packages and on the outside of vehicles to warn drivers and others of the presence of hazardous materials. It is the responsibility of the shipper to place the placards, and it is the responsibility of the driver to verify that the correct placards have been placed.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: What is the symbol for a marine pollutant?
questions.answerA: The image of a waves in a yellow triangle with an X through through the waves
questions.answerB: The image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish
questions.answerC: A light blue square with a dark blue X through the square
questions.answerD: The image of a bird in a red octagon
questions.explanation: The marine pollutant marking is the image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish.

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerB: The address of the shipper.
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.answerB: Flammable.
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Placed in the glove box.
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Those around you.
questions.explanation: Due to the risks involved, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials. These regulations exist to protect the driver, others near the vehicle, and the environment.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Unless a package is clearly unsafe, what does the driver need to accept a package of hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.explanation: Unless a package is clearly unsafe or does not comply with the Hazardous Materials Regulations, you may accept the shipper's certification that it was properly packaged.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may be:
questions.answerA: Kept in a pouch attached to the driver's side door.
questions.answerB: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: What could indicate that a shipment you are accepting contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerB: Metallic.
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is by:
questions.answerB: Attending hazardous materials training courses.
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.answerB: Radioactive
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.answerB: Six
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: In the event of a fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerB: Throw water on the doors.
questions.answerC: Find someone else to open the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. In this case, leave the doors closed because opening the doors could worsen the fire by supplying it with more oxygen.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.answerB: Flammable.
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerB: At a truck stop.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: What can be a clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The shipper is a business you might expect to deal with hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The road is made of gravel.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical suppliers, scientific supply houses, pest control companies, agricultural suppliers, and dealers in explosives, fireworks, or munitions.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerB: In a safe haven.
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: What does a material’s hazard class reflect?
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will fall into one of nine hazard classes. The material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.answerB: Class 2
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerB: With electric lights.
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: When accepting a package of hazardous materials, a driver should ensure:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: That all packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: When carrying hazardous materials, it is a good idea to compare the shipping papers to the markings and labels on the packages.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerB: Are required for all shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: Unless excepted, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerB: The address of the shipper.
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: Unless excepted, hazardous materials shipping papers must list an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Greased.
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tires.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: What does a hazardous materials shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Removed.
questions.explanation: On a compressed gas tank, liquid discharge valves must always be kept closed, except during loading and unloading.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerB: Value of the materials.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerB: By eyeballing it.
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerB: Must be a licensed firefighter.
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.answerB: Radioactive
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Sign, but only if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Sign, but only if the weather was hazardous.
questions.explanation: A Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest must be signed by hand. The name and EPA registration number of the shippers, carriers, and destination must also appear on the manifest.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: If accepting a shipment, what could indicate that the cargo contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged on wood pallets.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: What does a shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: Among other information, shipping papers must include a description of the specific hazardous materials being transported.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: During an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: Five inches
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: Be sure that your wheel bearing/seals are:
questions.answerB: Shiny.
questions.explanation: During an inspection, ensure that the wheel bearing/seals are not leaking.

questions.question: To prevent trailers from rolling over, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Drive slowly around corners.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when pulling trailers, you should drive slowly when turning, drive slowly on curves, and generally steer gently and smoothly. When loading the trailers, you should keep the cargo as low to the ground as possible.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance of driving to:
questions.answerA: Recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: When a tire goes flat, you may hear a loud bang. The truck will be affected:
questions.answerB: After a short delay.
questions.answerC: Only if the damaged tire is near the front of the truck.
questions.answerD: Only if the truck is hauling a load.
questions.explanation: There may be a delay of a few seconds between the sound of a tire failing and the time that the vehicle is affected by the tire failure. Because of the short delay, a driver may initially believe that the sound came from another vehicle.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that you could impede other vehicles, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with your emergency flashers activated.
questions.answerD: Wave an arm out of your window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive slowly, you should use your emergency flashers to warn other drivers. Be sure that the use of emergency flashers is permitted by local laws.

questions.question: If planning to stop on the road to unload cargo, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop suddenly, since you are already on the road.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers by tapping your brakes.
questions.answerC: Wave your arm out the window to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should tap your brakes and flash your brake lights to warn other drivers any time you plan to slow or stop where other drivers may not expect you to do so. Use this technique when stopping on the road to unload cargo or passengers.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Take drugs to keep awake.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: A burning tire should be:
questions.answerB: Fanned with a blanket.
questions.explanation: A burning tire should be cooled with water. A driver may need to use large quantities of water to properly cool the tire.

questions.question: Slow down and be extra careful:
questions.answerB: When driving on dry pavement.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be especially careful when driving in and around work zones, in places where the pavement drops off sharply at the edge of the road, when foreign objects are present on the road, and on freeway on- and off-ramps.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerB: Usually has slowed perception.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Release the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: In an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerB: Not always respond by stopping.
questions.answerD: Always turn on your flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest option when responding to an emergency while driving. It is usually safer to steer out of the way when attempting to avoid a crash.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerB: Your speed will decrease.
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: When driving, keeping space between your vehicle and other vehicles is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.explanation: For the safety of everyone on the road, it is essential that you maintain adequate cushions of space between your vehicle and other vehicles. This will help ensure that if you need to stop your vehicle, you will be able to do so without hitting someone else.

questions.question: If a vehicle gets stuck on a railroad track, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the vehicle and try to restart the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Try to flag down another vehicle to give them a push.
questions.answerD: Wait in the vehicle for a law enforcement officer to arrive.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, immediately exit the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check signs or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information. Call the emergency contact or call 911.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerB: Are only used on tucks carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Allow drivers to stay in control when braking.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheels from locking up during a hard application of brakes.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull off the roadway.
questions.explanation: If someone is tailgating you, it is a good idea to open up the space ahead of your vehicle to make it easier for the driver to pass you. Increasing your speed is not a good idea because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when air pressure drops to a level between:
questions.answerB: 75 and 105 psi.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: On a leaf spring, the leaves:
questions.answerB: Are not required.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: What is traction?
questions.answerA: Friction between the tires and road
questions.answerB: Tires' rates of rotation
questions.answerC: The length of time needed to activate the brakes
questions.explanation: Traction is friction between your tires and the surface of the road. Adequate traction is necessary for braking and steering.

questions.question: When testing ____, you should apply your vehicle's brakes with the hand control while moving the vehicle forward slowly.
questions.answerB: The emergency braking system
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: How much space should be between the upper and lower fifth wheel?
questions.answerB: A maximum of two inches of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.answerB: May not affect
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi, the air compressor governor will:
questions.answerA: Stop the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: Release air from the tanks.
questions.answerC: Begin pumping air into the tanks.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level around 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: If something is found to be unsafe during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue with the trip and make an appointment with a mechanic after the trip is completed.
questions.answerB: Let a more experienced driver use the truck.
questions.answerD: Not use the items found to be unsafe, but may continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals anything unsafe about your vehicle, you must get it repaired. It is illegal to operate an unsafe vehicle.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged at all speeds.
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerB: Not change the way you apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same way that you would in a vehicle without ABS. It will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only required during interstate travel.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake repeatedly.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: If you don't pull a dolly out from beneath the rear trailer before unlocking the pintle hook:
questions.answerA: The tow bar may fly up.
questions.answerB: The kingpin may break.
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer. This could cause the dolly tow bar to fly up, possibly causing serious injury.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerB: At a fixed rate.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower will not speed up the process. The only way to become sober is to allow your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: Wheel rims that have been welded should:
questions.answerA: Be placed in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Be placed in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Wheels and rims with welding repairs are not safe to be used. Replace any damaged wheels and rims.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: A sign indicating a maximum safe speed:
questions.answerA: Is suggesting a driving speed, but vehicles may travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.answerB: Is suggesting a speed limit to be followed only by vehicles weighing more than 26,000 pounds.
questions.answerC: Should be followed and no vehicle should travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.explanation: You should never exceed the speed shown on a "Maximum Safe Speed" sign.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Avoid using your mirrors while in heavy traffic.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.answerB: Away from heat sources.
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents a truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from driving too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.answerB: It increases slightly.
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Sign, but only if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Sign, but only if the weather was hazardous.
questions.explanation: A Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest must be signed by hand. The name and EPA registration number of the shippers, carriers, and destination must also appear on the manifest.

questions.question: A vehicle that is smaller than your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Will usually be able to stop faster than your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Will usually take more time to stop than your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will take about the same amount of time to stop as your vehicle.
questions.explanation: In general, a smaller vehicle will be able to come to a complete stop faster than a larger vehicle. Keep this in mind when determining your following distance.

questions.question: Transporting liquid cargo:
questions.answerB: Is no different than hauling solid cargo.
questions.answerC: Is easier than transporting gas or solid cargo.
questions.explanation: Due to the movement of the liquid in transit and the vehicle's high center of gravity, hauling liquid cargo in a tank vehicle requires special care.

questions.question: If required to complete a vehicle inspection report in writing, the report must be signed:
questions.answerB: Only if defects have been noted and certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: Only if the repairs are estimated to cost more than $1,000.
questions.answerD: Only if requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: You must sign the previous vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and certified to have been repaired or not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: In an engine compartment, loose belts will:
questions.answerA: Not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, causing the engine to overheat.
questions.answerB: Make the engine run more efficiently.
questions.answerC: Make the fan run too much, causing the engine to run too coolly.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check the tightness of the belts in your engine compartment. Loose belts will not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, which can lead the engine overheating.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should:
questions.answerB: Be used only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Be used together with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve works the trailer brakes but should only be used when testing them. Using it while driving could create a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerB: Daydreaming
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: A tank should never be transported if:
questions.answerB: The tank is partially filled.
questions.answerC: The cargo is a hazardous material.
questions.explanation: It is illegal transport liquids or gases in a leaking tank. Always make sure that intake, discharge, and cut-off valves are in the correct positions before loading, unloading, or moving a tank vehicle.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires on the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs should never be used.

questions.question: When checking your tires, which of the following is not an issue to correct?
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerD: Tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch on the front tires
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting tires include: air pressure that is too low or too high; using radial and bias-ply tires together; tread depth of less than 4/32 of an inch in major grooves on front tires; and tread depth of less than 2/32 of an inch on all other tires.

questions.question: If you notice anything affecting the safety or mechanical functioning of your CMV while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay quiet and see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Make a written report that includes your concerns.
questions.explanation: At the end of each day of driving, you may be required to make a written report on the vehicle or vehicles driven. Be sure to make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you are not confident that your vehicle will have enough room to safely pass under an overhead object, you should slow down and seek another route, if possible.

questions.question: Talking on a hands-free phone while driving:
questions.answerB: Only distracts the driver if the driver is speaking.
questions.answerC: Can be distracting to the driver.
questions.explanation: While speaking on a hands-free phone while driving is less dangerous than speaking on a hand-held phone, it is just as likely to mentally distract a driver. Simply engaging in conversation takes their mental focus away from the task of driving.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will often continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerB: The trailer may disengage.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: An after-trip inspection should be done:
questions.answerB: Once a month.
questions.explanation: You should always complete an after-trip inspection of your vehicle at the end of a trip, day, or tour of duty. Complete a vehicle inspection report, if required.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate especially slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To keep from accelerating faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under slippery conditions. Using too much power in such conditions may cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.answerB: Not change.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase. When approaching a downgrade, choose to travel at a speed that will be safe for the size and weight of your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following does not indicate bad brakes?
questions.answerB: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
